awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Development of an Experimental Methodology to Probe Crack Tip Chemistry and Electrochemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
Ever growing attention is being given to the issue of aging infrastructure in the United States, and metals utilized in these applications, including aluminum and steel, must withstand demanding mechanical loads and corrosive environmental conditions. When mechanical loads are present with a corrosive environment, a phenomenon referred to as environment assisted cracking (EAC) can occur.  EAC is material degradation that occurs because of the deleterious interaction of mechanical stresses and an external corrosive environment causing crack initiation at stress levels lower than expected and crack growth faster than expected. Routine safety inspections to check for damage are a component of maintenance cost that could be reduced if component failure and life prediction models increased accuracy by including the effects of EAC. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports the development of an experimental technique that can directly probe and alter the environmental conditions within a growing crack, providing a tool to generate the data and knowledge necessary to enhance life prediction models.

Environment Assisted Cracking (EAC) occurs via corrosion and mechanical processes localized near the crack tip.  Therefore, knowledge of crack tip conditions is vital to understanding the mechanism driving EAC. Little experimental verification of the crack environment over a wide range of material systems and external environments has been done. The work under this award will develop an experimental methodology for probing and/or altering both the chemical and electrochemical (pH and electrochemical potential) conditions within a growing EAC crack to enable both short-term and long-term research initiatives that directly probe crack tip conditions and understand EAC mechanisms in a wide range of alloy and bulk environment conditions. To do this, the research team will re-design a corrosion fatigue fracture mechanics specimen to have small holes (1 mm or less in diameter) used to insert micro-electrodes capable of measuring pH and electrochemical potential or tubing to extract or inject electrolyte for chemical analysis.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this EAGER project was to develop an experimental methodology for probing and/or altering both the chemical and electrochemical conditions within a growing corrosion fatigue crack, both near the crack tip and along the crack wake. The first achievement to reach this objective was to modify a currently established fracture mechanics sample in a way that would allow for access to a growing crack without invalidating the ability to utilize the sample for controlled fracture mechanics fatigue testing. This was accomplished by drilling small probe holes top down into a compact tension ASTM standard specimen that terminated along the anticipated fracture plane.  Tests were conducted on a standard sample, a sample with holes drilled at various locations along the sample, and samples with pH micro-electrodes inserted.  Results from this program show that the sample remains valid with holes and pH micro-electrodes inserted. Specifically, the crack growth rate remained unchanged with all modifications.  The second achievement to reach the stated objective was to actively measure the pH with the micro-electrodes in an actively growing crack.  To do this, tests were conducted in a sodium chloride solution with a pH of 7 on AA7075-T6.  Once the crack reached the location of the hole containing the micro-electrode, the electrode read a crack tip pH of 3.  This acidic pH for an Al-Zn-Mg-Cu alloy is in agreement with modeling estimates in the literature that establish a more acidic near crack tip solution than that of the bulk solution.  Additionally, a pH value of 3 is in agreement with literature reports by Cooper and Kelly on measured crack tip pH of a stress corrosion crack in a similar Al-Zn-Mg-Cu alloy.  In all, the results of this project establish that the technique developed can be utilized to actively measure pH of an actively growing corrosion fatigue crack.

Due to limitations in samples and time, the crack solution conditions were not able to be altered or probe to measure electrolyte composition.  Although, similar probes to those utilized for pH are available commercially and could be utilized for the purpose of measure chloride concentration and potential amongst other things.

The broader impacts of this work are that three post-doctoral research associates were trained in the area of environment assisted cracking of aluminum alloys.  One of these post-doctoral research associates has since taken a job in industry for a company producing aerospace aluminum alloys. In the long-term, this capability can be utilized over a wide range of material and environment systems to confirm current modeling assumptions on crack chemistry and electrochemistry and generate the data necessary to inform first principle models that can solve the disagreement on the mechanistic driver for environment assisted cracking.  This last item could be most influential as it would allow the creation of life prediction models from first principles. 

Products both produced and anticipated are:

L.G. Bland and J.S. (Warner) Locke, Chemical and Electrochemical Conditions within Stress Corrosion and Corrosion Fatigue Cracks, npj Materials Degradation, Oct 2017. doi:10.1038/s41529-017-0015-0. http://rdcu.be/wMI3

S.N. Esmaeely, J. Pope, D. McAllister, J. Locke; Measurement of Corrosion Fatigue Crack Solution pH in Actively Growing Cracks, Poser at Aqueous Corrosion Gordon Conference, July 2018.

Manuscript in preparation: S.N. Esmaeely, J. Pope, D. McAllister, J. (Warner) Locke; Established Technique to Measure Corrosion Fatigue Crack Solution pH in Actively Growing Cracks

 


Last Modified: 07/31/2018
Modified by: Jenifer S Locke
